💡 What is an MVP? A Minimum Viable Product (MVP) is a simplified version of your product built to validate market demand as early as possible. It contains just enough features to deliver value to real users and test whether your solution resonates with the target audience. While a Proof of Concept (POC) is typically internal and focused on validating technical feasibility, the MVP is external and customer-focused—designed to learn from real-world usage.   🚀 Why build an MVP? An MVP allows your team to: Launch a usable version of your product fast.Start testing your value proposition in the market with real users.Gather feedback to improve product-market fit before scaling up.An MVP isn’t about building less, it’s about building the right things first. It's not just a prototype—it should offer a functional experience that solves a real problem, even if it’s minimal.   ⚠️ Keep in mind: An MVP should feel like a complete experience, even if it’s simple under the hood. Don’t focus on building a perfect version—focus on learning quickly. What matters is whether users get value and keep coming back. MVPs are often small in scope but big in insight. The example on the right illustrates this well: don't build a wheel if the user needs a ride. Start with something like a skateboard—usable, valuable, and improvable.   📚 Learn More:   This bootcamp follows the Design Sprint methodology created at Google Ventures.  Explore the full framework here: https://www.gv.com/sprint/ We use Miro as a collaborative space to guide you through each step of the Sprint — visually and interactively.

Welcome to the Aptos MVP Bootcamp Miro Board This board is your workspace for the bootcamp and it is designed to help you define, shape, and accelerate your Minimum Viable Product (MVP) on Aptos.   Over the next few days, you’ll move through a hands-on Design Sprint built to help you: Validate a real, high-impact problemScope your MVP and define what not to buildClarify your Aptos integration and technical architectureBuild your GTM thinking and product narrative  Every section here maps directly to what you’ll need to build, validate, and fund over the coming weeks, this is your foundation.   🔎 By the end of Sprint Week, you’ll walk away with: A clear product pitchA realistic development roadmapA sharp problem statement and user flow  🚀 By the end of the full program, you’ll have: A functional Proof of ConceptA refined roadmap and pitchEverything ready to present at Demo Day and submit for Aptos Foundation grants  📌 Before you begin: Explore the board, section by section. 🎯 What is the goal of this exercise?  Before defining your product or features, you need to explore the full range of problems your project could solve. This exercise is about brainstorming as many relevant and important issues as possible — especially those that are real pain points for users. Your goal is quantity over perfection — the refinement comes later. ✨ What does it mean to brainstorm problems?  Brainstorming problems means generating a wide list of challenges, frustrations, or unmet needs that your target users experience in a particular domain or context. Don’t try to craft perfect statements or narrow things down just yet. Instead, explore every angle of what feels broken or inefficient in your users’ world. These could include:  - Pain points in their current experience  - Barriers that prevent them from completing a task  - Unmet needs they try to work around  - Frustrations they regularly express     ⏳ How to Complete This Exercise (15 minutes) 1. Set a timer for 10 minutes — This is a fast-paced brainstorming session. Don’t overthink or self-edit. 2. Individually or with your team, write down as many user problems as you can 3. Use sticky notes or a Miro frame — 1 problem per note.   💡 Pro Tip  When listing problems, try to frame them from the user’s perspective and avoid vague phrasing like “the lack of...”. Instead, write them as: “Users struggle to…” “People feel frustrated when…” “It’s hard for users to…”

🎯 What is the goal of this exercise? Now that you’ve surfaced a wide range of user problems, it’s time to narrow your focus. The goal here is to identify the 1 to 3 most important problems your project will tackle in the next 2–3 months of development. This becomes the core of your product direction. You’ll also be asked to translate those problems into clear, user-centered problem statements, which will guide your design, development, and communication.   ✨ What is a Problem Statement?  A problem statement is a precise, user-focused way to describe a real issue — not a missing feature or your imagined solution. A good problem statement is:  - Focused on the user’s experience  - Grounded in what’s actually broken  - Free from assumptions about the solution 🚫 Avoid: “There’s no platform that helps creators monetize NFTs.” (This already suggests a platform is the answer.) ✅ Instead: “Independent creators struggle to earn consistent income from their NFT work despite having an engaged audience.” (This describes the pain, not the fix.)   ⏳ How to Complete This Exercise (15 minutes) - Review your brainstormed problems (5 min) - Group similar ideas where needed. - Prioritize 1 to 3 key problems (5 min) - Summarize them into a singular Problem Statement

🎯 What is the goal of this exercise?  You can’t build a product for “everyone.” To create something meaningful, you need to understand who you’re building for and what their world looks like. This exercise helps you define clear user personas — archetypes that represent the goals, needs, and behaviors of your key user segments. These personas will guide your design decisions, prioritize your features, and sharpen your communication throughout the Bootcamp and beyond.   ✨ What is a User Persona? A user persona is a fictional-yet-realistic profile that captures the essence of a particular type of user — their goals, frustrations, and how they behave. Personas are not guesses or just demographic snapshots. They’re strategic tools to keep your team aligned on: Who your users are What they’re trying to achieve Why your product should exist for them You can (and should) create more than one persona if your product serves distinct groups. But the more personas you have the more complex your app will be.   ⏳ How to Complete This Exercise (10–15 minutes) Set a timer for 10–15 minutes - Keep it focused. If you’re unsure, work from your assumptions — you’ll refine with real user feedback later. Define 1–2 primary user personas   📚 Additional Resources How to Create User Personas with Examples

It ignores edge cases and exceptions, and focuses only on the steps where your product creates the most value. 🎯 What is the goal of this exercise?  Now that you've mapped your ideal user journey, it’s time to break it down into real user actions. This exercise uses User Story Mapping to help you identify what needs to be built at each step of your Golden Path so you can deliver a product that actually works for your users.   ✨ What is User Story Mapping?  User Story Mapping breaks down your high-level user journey into the actual tasks and interactions that users go through at each step. This includes:  - What users do  - What they need to see or understand -  What options or tools help them move forward By expanding each Golden Path step, you’ll expose what needs to be designed, built, or clarified — and prepare for the MoSCoW prioritization.   ⏳ How to Complete This Exercise (20–25 minutes)  - Copy your Golden Path steps (from previous exercise) across the top of your board.  Limit: 5–6 main steps.  - For each step, list out detailed user actions below. Include:    - Screens, forms, and buttons    - Required data or decisions  - Think like a user:   - What are they trying to do at this step?   - What might slow them down?   - What would help them move forward smoothly?   📚 Additional Resource Intro to User Story Mapping (Jeff Patton)

🎯 What is the goal of this exercise?  You’ve mapped out the full user experience — now it’s time to prioritize what to build and when. Using the MoSCoW method, you’ll break your product plan into three stages: What you’ll build in the next 3 weeks (POC) What comes next (MVP) What comes later (MMP) This will help you stay lean, deliver value fast, and clearly communicate your product roadmap.   ✨ What is the MoSCoW Method?  MoSCoW is a prioritization framework that helps you decide what features Must, Should, Could, and Won’t be included — based on impact and timing. You’ll apply this to the user actions and tasks identified in your User Story Map. Define your roadmap in three phases: 🧪 POC (Proof of Concept) — What you’ll build during the next 3 weeks (core flow only) 🚀 MVP (Minimum Viable Product) — What comes next (3–4 months) for pilot testing or grant milestones 🛠️ MMP (Minimum Marketable Product) — What you'd launch in a real market (6–12 months)   ⏳ How to Complete This Exercise (15–20 minutes)  - Review your User Story Map   - Focus on the user actions and features you listed under each step.  - Sort each task using MoSCoW:  - Must Have – Critical for your POC to function  - Should Have – Needed for your MVP  - Could Have – Nice to have but not essential for initial testing  - Won’t Have (for now) – Out of scope, revisit later  - Assign each task to a phase:   - POC = Only Must Haves   - MVP = Must + Should Haves   💡 Tip: Keep your POC tight. If it’s not testable within 3 weeks, it doesn’t belong there.

🎯 What is the goal of this exercise?  To craft a clear, concise, and compelling one-sentence pitch that captures the essence of your product. A great one-liner should quickly answer:  - What your product is  - Who it's for -  What problem it solves or benefit it provides It’s not a slogan or a mission statement — it’s a crisp summary that helps people instantly “get it.”   ⏳ How to Complete This Exercise (10 minutes)  - Set a timer for 10 minutes  - Draft 2–3 variations of your one-liner  - Read each one aloud — does it feel clear? 🎯 What is the goal of this exercise?  To estimate the effort required for each user story in your POC, so you can better plan your development timeline and identify potential risks early.   ✨ What is sizing and why does it matter? Sizing means assigning a relative effort level to each user story using simple buckets — from Small (S) to Extra Large (XL). This helps you:  - Understand which tasks are quick wins  - Spot complex or risky work that needs breaking down  - Plan your sprint realistically A rough estimate is enough here — precision comes later.   ⏳ How to Complete This Exercise (20 minutes) Review your POC user stories from your story map. Estimate each story’s size using this guide: S (Small): ~1–2 days (2 points) — e.g., “Create login form” M (Medium): ~2–3 days (3 points) — e.g., “Design landing page with dynamic content” L (Large): ~5–10 days (5 points) — e.g., “Set up user roles and permissions” XL (Extra Large): ~1 full sprint (8 points) — e.g., “Build admin dashboard with analytics” If a story is L or XL, break it down into smaller parts — no L's XLs should remain.

🎯 What is the goal of this exercise?  To create low-fidelity wireframes that visually map out your app’s layout and user flows. These mockups will help you and your team align on the structure, key screens, and core interactions — before diving into design or development.   ✨ What is a Low-Fidelity Wireframe?  A low-fidelity wireframe is a simple sketch of a screen — no colors, no detailed styling, just the layout. It shows: Where buttons, text, and forms go How users move from one screen to the next What happens at each step in the user journey Think of it as a blueprint for your product’s UX — quick to make and easy to change.   ⏳ How to Complete This Exercise (30–45 minutes) Choose your tool — use the provided wireframe tool, Figma, Miro, or even pen and paper. Create 3–5 core screens per user journey based on your Golden Path. Keep it simple — use boxes, labels, and arrows. Focus on flow, not design.   💡 Tip: Imagine watching someone use your app for the first time. What do they need to see, understand, and do — and in what order?

🎯 What is the goal of this exercise?  To define and document the technical architecture of your solution using the C4 model. This high-level overview will help you and others — including Aptos technical reviewers — understand how your system works, how its parts connect, and how it interacts with the Aptos blockchain and other external systems.   ✨ What are C4 Diagrams?  The C4 model breaks down a software system into four layers of abstraction — from the big picture to detailed components. It's a clear, structured way to visualize your architecture:  - Context Diagram – Shows how your system fits into the larger environment (users, external systems, Aptos components, etc.)  - Container Diagram – Outlines the major pieces of your system (e.g., frontend, backend, databases, wallets)  - Component Diagram – Breaks down the internal structure of each container (e.g., modules, services, APIs)   ⏳ How to Complete This Exercise (60–90 minutes) Use the template provided (link from the Aptos team). This will guide your documentation and C4 layout. Start from the top down: Create a Context Diagram: Who uses your system? What external services does it talk to? Then define Containers: What are the main deployable pieces (frontend, backend, wallets, etc.)? Next, break those down into Components: APIs, smart contracts, services, modules   💡 Tip: Don’t overcomplicate it. Your goal is clarity — enough detail for someone technical to understand what you're building and how it's structured.
If you want to get diagrams just like these ones, you can use tools like PlantUML.

🎯 What’s the goal of this exercise?  To define and execute your first concrete steps to get early adopters using your product. Don’t wait for perfection—just focus on talking to real users now.   ✨ What is this tool?  This GTM Canvas is a quick and dirty framework to help you find your first beta testers and learn from them fast. It’s not about building a full marketing strategy—it’s about finding the shortest path to real feedback.   🌀 How the Early GTM Loop Works  Use this canvas to kick off your first loop: PLAN (Define your actions for the next 1–2 weeks) EXECUTE (Reach out, talk to users, put your offer in front of people) LEARN (What worked? What flopped?) ITERATE (Tweak your messaging, target, or tactics—and repeat)   🛠️ How to Use the Canvas (30–45 minutes)  Answer the following prompts to map out your first GTM sprint: Who is your ICP (Ideal Customer Profile)? What problem are you solving for them? Why should they care? What’s your hook or unique value? Where do they hang out? (Online communities, events, forums, etc.) What’s your offer or CTA? (Invite to beta, feedback session, etc.) What will you measure to learn? (Replies, signups, sessions, feedback) What are your next 3 concrete actions?
